title: 106_hr3272
content:
The "Keeping Families Together Act of 1999" includes provisions such as the restoration of the definition of aggravated felony, detention policy, repeal of time stop provisions, repeal of section 101(a)(48), restoration of section 212(c), and restoration of judicial review provisions. The "Keeping Families Together Act of 1999" repeals section 321 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996, restoring the provisions of law affected by it. It also allows affected aliens to apply for adjustment of status or cancellation of removal. Additionally, the Act includes the restoration of detention policy. The amendment to Section 236(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act mandates the detention of criminal aliens convicted of aggravated felonies upon release, without the possibility of release by the Attorney General. The amendment to Section 236(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act requires the detention of criminal aliens convicted of aggravated felonies upon release, with no chance of release by the Attorney General. This applies regardless of whether the alien was lawfully admitted or not, as long as they do not pose a danger and are likely to appear for scheduled proceedings. The amendment is effective retroactively to the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF TIME STOP PROVISIONS.

    Repeals Section 240A(d) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1229b(d)).

SEC. 5. REPEAL OF SECTION 101(A)(48).

    Repeals Paragraph (48) of section 101(a)(48) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1101(a)).

SEC. 6. RESTORATION OF SECTION 212(C). The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow aliens with permanent residence to return after voluntarily going abroad for up to seven years without deportation orders. The Attorney General has discretion in admitting these individuals, with exceptions for aggravated felons. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow permanent residents to return after voluntarily going abroad for up to seven years without deportation orders. A term of imprisonment of at least 5 years is mandated for certain felonies. The effective date of the amendment is April 24, 1996. SEC. 7. RESTORATION OF JUDICIAL REVIEW PROVISIONS. Amends Section 242 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to allow judicial review of orders of removal. Sec. 242 of the Immigration and Nationality Act establishes the procedure for judicial review of final orders of removal against aliens in the United States. Judicial review must be filed within specific timeframes, and the venue is determined by the location of the administrative proceedings before an immigration judge. The Immigration and Nationality Act establishes the procedure for judicial review of final orders of removal against aliens in the United States. The action must be brought in the judicial circuit where the petitioner resides, and the petition is served on the Attorney General and the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Service of the petition stays the removal of the alien pending court determination, except in cases of aggravated felony. The Immigration and Nationality Act outlines the process for judicial review of removal orders for aliens in the US. The petition is served on the Attorney General and the Immigration and Naturalization Service, staying the alien's removal except in cases of aggravated felony. The court determines the petition based on the administrative record and the Attorney General's findings, which are conclusive if supported by substantial evidence. If a petitioner claims to be a US national and the claim is not frivolous, the court must address the issues presented. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for judicial review of removal orders for aliens in the US. The court can transfer proceedings to a district court for a de novo hearing on nationality claims. Review of a motion to reopen or reconsider an order is consolidated with the review of the order. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for judicial review of removal orders for aliens in the US. The validity of a removal order can be challenged in a criminal proceeding by a separate motion for judicial review before trial, especially regarding nationality claims. The court may conduct a de novo hearing on nationality issues if a genuine material fact is in question. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for judicial review of removal orders for aliens in the US. A de novo hearing on nationality issues may be conducted if a genuine material fact is in question. The determination of nationality shall be based on the administrative record and the Attorney General's findings of fact. If the removal order is invalidated, the indictment will be dismissed, and the US can appeal within 30 days. No alien can file a petition for review during a criminal proceeding. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for judicial review of removal orders for aliens in the US. The Attorney General is not required to defer removal of an alien after a removal order is issued, and the alien must still comply with certain sections of the Act. The Attorney General can detain an alien at any time after a removal order is issued. It is not necessary to print the record or briefs for review by the court. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for judicial review of removal orders for aliens in the US. Any alien held in custody pursuant to an order of removal may obtain judicial review by habeas corpus proceedings. An order of removal can be reviewed through habeas corpus proceedings if the alien has exhausted administrative remedies or has not departed from the US after the order was issued. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for judicial review of removal orders for aliens in the US through habeas corpus proceedings. A petition for review or habeas corpus must state if the order's validity has been upheld in prior judicial proceedings. A petition may only challenge whether the alien is the one described in the order. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for judicial review of removal orders for aliens in the US through habeas corpus proceedings. A petition for review or habeas corpus must state if the order's validity has been upheld in prior judicial proceedings. The court's jurisdiction is limited to determining whether the alien matches the description in the order, is an alien described in section 238(b)(2), has been convicted of an aggravated felony, and was afforded the required procedures. The amendment made by subsection (a) will take effect on the enactment date and apply to pending determinations with final administrative decisions or decisions where the period for seeking judicial review has not expired.
